responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Zephyr Enterprise Test Management Plugin Stores Credentials Insecurely
    analysis: |
      The Zephyr Enterprise Test Management plugin for Jenkins stores credentials insecurely.
      The plugin defines a custom configuration type called `ZephyrInstance` which includes fields
      for the server address, username, and password. When the user configures the plugin, these
      credentials are stored in the Jenkins `config.xml` file in plain text. This means that anyone
      with access to the Jenkins controller filesystem can read the credentials.

      An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by gaining access to the Jenkins controller
      filesystem and reading the `config.xml` file. The attacker could then use the credentials
      to access the Zephyr Enterprise server.
    cwe: CWE-522
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/com/thed/zephyr/jenkins/model/ZephyrInstance.java
      - src/main/java/com/thed/zephyr/jenkins/reporter/ZeeDescriptor.java
    classification: very promising
```

leads.headline: Zephyr Enterprise Test Management Plugin Stores Credentials Insecurely
leads.analysis:
The Zephyr Enterprise Test Management plugin for Jenkins stores credentials insecurely.
The plugin defines a custom configuration type called ZephyrInstance which includes fields
for the server address, username, and password. When the user configures the plugin, these
credentials are stored in the Jenkins config.xml file in plain text. This means that anyone
with access to the Jenkins controller filesystem can read the credentials.

An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by gaining access to the Jenkins controller
filesystem and reading the config.xml file. The attacker could then use the credentials
to access the Zephyr Enterprise server.
